image.title: DW.COM
image.description: News, Analysis and Service from Germany and Europe - in 30 Languages

item.title: Ukraine seeks negotiated deal on Azovstal troop evacuation — live updates
item.description: Ukrainian officials have said a new effort is underway to try and secure the evacuation of soldiers remaining in the Azovstal steelworks complex in Mariupol. DW has the latest.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Migrant boat capsizes near Puerto Rico leaving at least 11 dead
item.description: The US Coast Guard has said a vessel carrying mainly Haitian migrants capsized off the coast of Puerto Rico. More than 30 people were rescued and a search is ongoing.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: North Korea reports first COVID-19 death a day after admitting outbreak
item.description: State media in North Korea has reported the deaths of six people with a "fever" a day after officials confirmed the country's first COVID-19 infection. More than 180,000 people are said to be isolated for treatment.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: US: Top House Republicans subpoenaed by Capitol riot panel
item.description: Five House Republicans are said to have information relevant the storming of the US Capitol by supporters of former President Donald Trump. However, they all have refused to cooperate with the special investigation.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: G7 foreign ministers meet in Germany over 'global crisis' of Russia's Ukraine invasion
item.description: Diplomats from the world's wealthiest nations will meet for three days to tackle issues like massive global food shortages resulting from the war, as well as Ukraine's hopes of joining the EU.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Austria leads international bust of massive human trafficking ring
item.description: Authorities arrested 205 people tied to Central and Eastern European gangs smuggling tens of thousands of Syrians in the EU. The €150 million ring used Vienna as a hub to move migrants from Hungary to Germany and France.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Ukraine war, COVID: How German society is divided
item.description: How polarized is Germany? This question is controversially discussed at the European Police Congress. Result: It depends on who you ask.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: India redraws Kashmir political constituencies ahead of elections
item.description: Critics say India's redrawn constituencies for the former state of Jammu and Kashmir give greater representation to the Muslim-majority region's Hindu areas. The region has long been facing an anti-India insurgency.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Japan: Why are there so few women in top managerial roles?
item.description: Despite decades of promises that women would have the chance to "shine" in Japan's corporate and political worlds, the country lags behind other industrialized nations in gender equality.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Finland's NATO accession bid 'better late than never:' former PM Alexander Stubb
item.description: Finland will not be deterred by Russian threats from applying to join NATO, Finnish ex-Prime Minister Alexander Stubb says. He told DW that the country would be a major security asset for the alliance.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Astronomers present first image of black hole at center of Milky Way
item.description: Scientists theorize that "supermassive black holes" lie at the center of all galaxies, including our own. "Sagittarius A*" is orders of magnitude more dense than the sun but it's also quite some distance from Earth.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Denmark seeks prosecution of ex-minister for leaking state secrets
item.description: Danish media has suggested the charges are in connection to revelations of Denmark's cooperation with the NSA. The justice ministry has requested that lawmakers lift the ex-minister's immunity.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Tokyo's stylish public toilets inspire filmmaker Wim Wenders
item.description: The German director is making a film about public restrooms designed by renowned architects. The high-end toilets are the symbol of "Japan's world-renowned hospitality culture."
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Sri Lankans running out of food, fuel and medicine
item.description: Sri Lankans told DW how they're struggling with shortages of food, fuel and medicine as the nation faces one of its worst economic crises in decades.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Germany: Police launch terrorism probe against pupil
item.description: Police in the western German city of Essen are investigating allegations of planned school attacks by a pupil. Bomb-building materials were found at his home, an official said.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Shireen Abu Akleh: Outrage grows over Al Jazeera journalist's killing
item.description: Palestinian-American journalist and long-time Al Jazeera correspondent Shireen Abu Akleh was shot and killed while covering an Israeli military raid in the West Bank.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Ukraine: UN says 6 million have fled since Russian invasion — as it happened
item.description: The UN said 6 million Ukrainians have left country, while over a million have returned home. Meanwhile, Finland's leaders say it should join NATO "without delay."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: India: Elderly couple sue son over lack of grandchildren
item.description: An Indian couple has sued their son and daughter-in-law, demanding a grandchild. They say they invested in their son's education and wedding, and are therefore owed at least monetary compensation.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: COVID travel restrictions: Germany
item.description: Travel in Europe is subject to COVID-19 restrictions. The omicron variant has led to higher numbers of infections, which are often less severe. This is how Germany is responding to the current situation.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Priceless antique bust found in thrift shop to return to Germany
item.description: A woman bought a marble bust for $35 in a thrift shop in Texas. It turned out to be an invaluable antique that has been traced back — and will be returned — to Germany.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: NATO: New challenges for the alliance as Finland and Sweden inch closer to membership?
item.description: Finland has announced its decision to join NATO as quickly as possible, Sweden is expected to follow suit shortly. What does this mean for the alliance?
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Who was Ukrainian philosopher Hryhoriy Skovoroda?
item.description: The Soviet Union once honored Hryhoriy Skovoroda with a museum in Ukraine — that's now been destroyed by Russian bombs. It's an attack on a freedom-loving idol, says philologist Gusan Guseynov.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: What are the COVID entry rules for travelers to European countries?
item.description: Most European countries have lifted travel restrictions — despite ongoing high infection numbers. DW Travel has compiled this overview of EU rules.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Sri Lanka court bars ex-prime minister from leaving country
item.description: Mahinda Rajapaksa, who stepped down as prime minister this week, has been blocked from leaving Sri Lanka. Another former prime minister, Ranil Wickremesinghe, has been sworn in as his replacement.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Pussy Riot on tour following band co-founder's escape from Russia
item.description: One of the band's leaders, Maria Alyokhina, managed to escape house arrest disguised as a food courier. DW met Pussy Riot as they start their European tour.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Are we flushing away the answer to our fertilizer shortages?
item.description: All eyes are on our food systems as the Russia-Ukraine war further pushes up fertilizer prices. Scientists think our urine could be the solution to helping crops grow and strengthening food security.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: 'Cost-of-living' crisis hits consumers as UK economy struggles with inflation
item.description: A series of shocks have combined to send prices spiraling in the UK. Inflation is a global problem, but Boris Johnson's government is being accused of making things worse for consumers.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Ukraine to put first Russian soldier on trial for war crimes
item.description: Kyiv prosecutor Iryna Venediktova announced plans to hold the trial of a 21-year-old Russian soldier accused of killing a civilian. The soldier was allegedly told to shoot the victim in order to avoid detection.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Western luxury brands squeezed by Ukraine conflict may look further east
item.description: Western luxury brands may no longer sell many goods to Russians due to sanctions on Moscow. With a market worth billions now off limits and Russian clients enraged, fashion houses could look further east to compensate.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Digital pet Tamagotchi turns 25
item.description: Adorable, or annoying? The tiny digital egg beeped in the pockets of millions of children all over the world. But the hype surrounding the little nuisance ended as quickly as it began.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Results: This is your favorite flower!
item.description: Spring is well underway in Europe, breathing new life into the natural world. The first flowers to emerge from the ground include snowdrops, tulips, primulas, narcissi, hyacinths and crocuses.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ukraine among 10 first Eurovision finalists
item.description: A total of 17 songs were presented during the first semifinal of the Eurovision Song Contest. Viewers have selected 10 acts that will compete in the finals on Saturday.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Africa's COVID-19 vaccine production line in jeopardy
item.description: A year ago, South Africa celebrated the opening of the continent's first COVID-19 vaccine production line. Now it's at risk of being shut down due to low demand.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Wildfires in Russia: Will war in Ukraine limit firefighting response?
item.description: The fire season has started early in Siberia, as drought and strong winds fuel blazes in its carbon-rich peat forests. But with Russian forces fighting in Ukraine, this year's emergency response could suffer.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Opinion: UEFA ushers in Super League by stealth
item.description: In passing men's Champions League "reforms," football’s so-called protectors have let the game down, says Matt Pearson. The big clubs are once again getting what they want. In football, it seems that greed is god.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Documenta curators denounce 'racist effects' of 'antisemitism rumors'
item.description: Discussions on the topic of artistic freedom, which had planned to address accusations of antisemitism, were cancelled: The art show's curators, ruangrupa, have published an open letter on the accusations.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ukrainian troops arrive in Germany for howitzer training
item.description: Around 60 Ukrainian soldiers have arrived in western Germany to begin training on the howitzer 2000 artillery system. The German government has pledged to send seven of the self-propelled weapons.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Lufthansa apologizes for excluding Jewish group over mask rules
item.description: Lufthansa apologized for excluding a group of Jewish passengers after a few were not observing COVID protocols. The group consisted of the visibly Jewish Orthodox, who accused the airline of collective punishment.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Karim Adeyemi moves to Borussia Dortmund as Erling Haaland departs
item.description: Shortly after Erling Haaland's move to Manchester City was confirmed, Borussia Dortmund announced the signing of Karim Adeyemi. The Germany forward moves from Haaland's old club in Austria.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Global warming: World has 50-50 chance of hitting 1.5C mark soon
item.description: The average global temperature could exceed 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels by 2026, UN meteorologists say. The threshold is one that international agreements are trying to prevent.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: How devastating is a DDoS cyberattack?
item.description: Last weekend, Russian hackers attacked several German government websites. These cyberattacks were seemingly harmless, much to the relief of the authorities. But many others are not so lucky.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: UEFA agrees Champions League reforms
item.description: UEFA has announced changes to the format of the Champions League starting in 2024-25. Meanwhile, Berlin's Olympiastadion has been awarded the final of Euro 2024, which is to be hosted by Germany.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Erling Haaland to Man City leaves Borussia Dortmund with only memories
item.description: Erling Haaland has agreed to join English champions Manchester City. Haaland's performances for Dortmund have been spellbinding and the club are left with the impossible task of replacing one of Europe's finest players.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Exiled Ukrainian musicians create orchestra in Germany
item.description: Musicians from Ukraine have founded an exile orchestra in Germany. They are now performing classical works at the Berliner Philharmonie.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: How Lithuania is freeing itself from Russian energy
item.description: A new pipeline is connecting the Baltic states with Poland, ergo with the entire European gas network. For Poland, it's been a lifesaver. For Lithuania, it's just one part of a much larger scheme.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: New Bob Dylan Center explores his creative process
item.description: The center in Tulsa, Oklahoma, is dedicated to the cultural significance of the elusive songwriter, and houses over 100,000 items from the musician's archives.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Pulitzer Prizes honor Ukrainian journalists, January 6 coverage
item.description: The US' most prestigious journalism prizes have gone to newsrooms and individuals covering conflict, public health, and social issues.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Eurovision Song Contest 2022 favorites
item.description: In Turin, paticipants are busy rehearsing for the Eurovision Song Contest, which opened on Sunday evening and will culminate on May 14. Take a look!
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Marking history: the Pulitzer Prize
item.description: John F. Kennedy, Watergate and the Panama Papers; Janet Cooke's fake news or Maureen Dowd's biting op-eds: Here's a look back at the rich history of the Pulitzer, the US' top awards for writing.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Art in exile: Afghan Sara Nabil fights for women's rights
item.description: Radical and direct: Afghan artist Sara Nabil employs her art to denounce women's oppression in her home country. Kunsthalle Mannheim is now showing her works.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ultra-long-haul flights: Your body and mental health
item.description: Qantas will offer non-stop ultra-long-haul flights from Australia to the US and Europe. How will the 20-hour flights affect your mental and physical health?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: China's export growth slows sharply as zero-COVID rules hit economy
item.description: China's zero-COVID policies are beginning to severely hit the country's global export engine. Prolonged lockdowns led to particularly sluggish export growth in April, new figures show.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: 2022 Jazzfest Bonn features prominent line-up
item.description: Founded more than a decade ago, the Jazzfest Bonn has grown into one of Europe's major jazz festivals, bringing the musical genre to bigger audiences in Germany.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Why do humans eat so much meat?
item.description: We know the current meat and dairy industry are harming our planet and that eating too much animal protein can even be bad for our health. So why do humans continue eating meat?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: NashStore: Russia's alternative to the Google Play store
item.description: Google Play is restricted in Russia as part of Western sanctions over the invasion of Ukraine. A domestic alternative is set to launch soon after a testing phase.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Turkey's tourism sector battling fallout from the war in Ukraine
item.description: Last year, most foreign tourists in Turkey came from Russia, Germany and Ukraine. Two of the countries are at war. Visitor numbers are down — meaning tough times ahead for Turkey's tourist industry.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Germany: CDU wins Schleswig-Holstein state election
item.description: The conservative CDU has won by a wide margin in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, according to official results. The poll was seen as a test of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's response to the Ukraine war.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Wolfsburg reclaim Women's Bundesliga in some style
item.description: Bayern Munich wrestled the title from Wolfsburg last season, but the perennial women's Bundesliga champions have reclaimed it after a 10-1 win. Elsewhere Frankfurt are in good shape for Europe and Chelsea won the WSL.
item.dc:subject: NRS-Import

item.title: How Schalke 'reinvented' themselves to get back to the Bundesliga
item.description: One year ago, Schalke were relegated in a cloud of internal chaos and on the brink of insolvency. Twelve months later, the Royal Blues are back in the Bundesliga and on the long road to financial recovery.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Bayer Leverkusen strategy pays off with Champions League return
item.description: Bayer Leverkusen will return to the Champions League next season after a three-year absence. They got over the line with a typically topsy-turvy win that highlighted the long-term strategy the club has employed.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Will surging energy prices derail reforms in oil-exporting Middle East?
item.description: The Ukraine war has seen energy prices spike with oil producers in the Middle East making more money than ever. But will it put the brakes on long-planned reforms to diversify oil-reliant economies in the region?
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Borussia Dortmund cancel Israel trip after concerns raised
item.description: The post-season trip has been called off after members of Borussia Dortmund's team raised concerns due to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The Bundesliga runners-up were due to play a friendly against Maccabi Netanya.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Racism in Germany is part of everyday life
item.description: Most Germans recognize that racism exists in their society, affecting not only minorities but everybody who lives here. The country's first National Discrimination and Racism report has found some surprising results.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Western companies leave Russia — taking Russian jobs with them
item.description: More and more Russians are losing their jobs due to Western sanctions on Russia, and some are having to painfully rethink their future. With some sanctions' effects yet to be felt, the number of unemployed could grow.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Think 8 hours of sleep is best? Think again!
item.description: Are you 38 or older? Then you may want to rethink how much sleep you truly need. A team of international researchers has found that less is more.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Ukraine: How farm vehicles stolen by Russia were remotely disabled
item.description: Russian soldiers looted combine harvesters and tractors worth millions of dollars from Ukraine, according to a media report. But the machinery was deactivated remotely before it could be put to use.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Bitcoin boom spikes amid perceived risks
item.description: Central African Republic and El Salvador have made Bitcoin legal tender and Panama has approved a bill to regulate crypto assets. Experts warn that nations that adopt crypto currencies risk instability.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: What are millets and can they help create global food security?
item.description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has pushed food insecurity onto the table. Could an overlooked cereal help steady the situation and feed the global population in an era of climate crisis?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Ukraine: How drones are changing the way of war
item.description: The war in Ukraine shows that unmanned aerial vehicles are part of modern warfare. Drones have various tasks from aerial surveillance to missile defense.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: German Overshoot Day: 'We cannot continue like this'
item.description: Germany has used more resources in the first third of 2022 than are sustainably available to it for an entire year. Here's what needs to change.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: COVID: Omicron subvariants 'escaping the previous immunity'
item.description: You may be at risk of catching the new subvariants BA.4 or BA.5 even if you had the original omicron, virologist Alex Sigal told DW's Science Unscripted.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Can Algeria contribute to the EU's energy security?
item.description: Timely decisions, long-term commitments and a broader vision could help the European Union increase ties with the Western Mediterranean. Algeria, with its large reserves, could enhance the bloc's energy security.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Will buying cars online really take off?
item.description: Boosted by the popularity of electric automaker Tesla, more people than ever are buying vehicles online. UBS estimates the web will make up half of all car sales by 2030, but what will that mean for traditional dealers?
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Breed accounts for less than 10% of a dog's behavior
item.description: If you're looking for a dog with a specific personality, its breed will tell you less than the environment in which it is raised, a new study suggests.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Will an EU oil embargo put the lights out at Schwedt's refinery?
item.description: As EU member states push for a Russian oil embargo, Germany's PCK Schwedt refinery is facing an uncertain future. It runs wholly on Russian imports, and many locals aren't so sure alternatives can be found in time.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Carbon farming: Climate change solution or greenwashing?
item.description: European agriculture produces millions of tons of CO2 every year. Could encouraging farmers to capture carbon on their land to sell credits to businesses help reduce emissions?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Germans split over heavy weapons deliveries to Ukraine
item.description: The German public is divided on the issue of military support for Ukraine. Many fear the delivery of tanks and training of Ukrainian soldiers in Germany may drag the country into the war.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Is India facing a post-pandemic employment crisis?
item.description: India's job market is tightening, and skilled workers are finding it harder to enter the workforce. Government job drives and the informal economy have been unable to make up the difference.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Record-breaking heat waves show we need to adapt to the climate crisis now
item.description: India is just the latest country to face life-threatening temperatures before summer has even started. As extreme heat becomes more frequent around the world, how can affected areas adapt to remain livable?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Russia posts trained dolphins at Black Sea naval base, satellite images show
item.description: Dolphin pens were moved to the Black Sea naval base around the time Russia invaded Ukraine, according to the US Naval Institute's analysis of satellite imagery.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Elvira Nabiullina: The central banker Vladimir Putin is relying on to clean up Russia's economic mess
item.description: Elvira Nabiullina has charmed many in the West with her policymaking — and clothing choices. Analysts say she has blemished her reputation by remaining at the helm to help sustain Putin's war machine in Ukraine.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: About a million people live near dangerous dams in Brazil
item.description: Data analysis by DW reveals many Brazilians live near dams that, without proper maintenance and governmental oversight, could be deadly in the case of failure.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Putin and Parkinson's: What experts say about his health
item.description: A video released by the Kremlin last weekend shows Putin in seemingly bad health. Some commentators and tabloids claim he has Parkinson's. What do doctors think?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Swiping right on climate love: Dating apps and environmental advocacy
item.description: Dating platforms have noticed their users are hot for climate issues and are incorporating features to help them connect with each other. But how useful are additions like OkCupid's climate advocate badge?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Germany top buyer of Russian energy since Ukraine invasion began: report
item.description: Russian fossil fuel exports are undermining sanctions imposed on the Kremlin over its invasion of Ukraine, a study says. Germany and the EU remain the biggest buyers of Russian energy.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Mars probe discovers 'shocking' new aurora
item.description: The Emirates Mars Mission says it's a first: They have spotted a worm-like aurora that stretches halfway round Mars. It looks like our northern lights.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Turning the tide on land degradation
item.description: Human activity has led to widespread land degradation and put our very survival as a species at risk. But by reversing course, we can tackle climate change and biodiversity loss — and make a better life for billions.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Endometriosis: The long wait for a diagnosis
item.description: Sabrina Lobing waited more than a decade for a diagnosis that explained her symptoms. Now she knows she has endometriosis — a disease that little is known about and yet is very common.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Scientists sound alarm bells on noise pollution
item.description: The rumble of road traffic and trains, the bustle of the bar downstairs or the roar of a plane taking off – noise is a problem that is increasingly hurting health and disrupting ecosystems.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Beyond ecology: The trees at the heart of our culture
item.description: From Ireland to the Amazon to Kenya, trees can hold traditional or even sacred value. DW takes a look at trees and forests of cultural importance to communities around the world. Some are under threat.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Let's talk about salt — how unhealthy is it really?
item.description: Most people consume too much salt — with potentially massive effects for their health. But it's possible to find a healthy balance.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: So you want to live forever?
item.description: Spoiler: You probably won't be able to live forever, even if you want to. How about settling for a life free from age-related ailments like Alzheimer's or arthritis instead?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: COVID: In a crowd of unmasked people, can a mask still protect you?
item.description: Many countries around the world are easing mask mandates. If no one else is masking up, should you?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: From Mumbai to Paris, the cities investing in the planet
item.description: This Earth Day, we show how city councils and mayors have stepped up to boldly decarbonize in the face of national government inaction.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Climate crisis: How to cope with eco-anxiety
item.description: Does worrying about climate change keep you up at night? Growing numbers of people are struggling with eco-anxiety, or distress about the state of the planet. If you're one of them, these expert tips might help.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Glass windows kill billions of birds a year. Scientists are working to change that
item.description: Conservationists are trying to convince governments and building owners around the world to introduce changes to stop birds from flying into reflective glass. Experts say the solutions are surprisingly simple.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: New omicron variants: What we know so far
item.description: A new omicron subvariant, BA.2.12.1, is spreading in the US and India. German Health Minister Lauterbach has expressed concern about the highly contagious coronavirus variant. Here's what we know so far.
item.dc:subject: Science
